Balance SWEET SOUR BITTER SALTY UMAMI 
SAVORY SPICY COLOR 
PIGMENT SHAPE AROMATIC HOT 
WARM 
COLD TENDER 
SOFT CRISPY 
CRUNCHY
Balance is essential to give a contrasting experience to the diner. Keeping the surrounding collection of balance varialbes in mind will help you to create diversified meals that will please you clientele. New recipes that have a balance of the different aesthetics of food is very essential. Good solid cooking technique with a great deal of emphasis on developing flavor and texture contrasts can make a dish very successful. Sweet refers to flavors coming from the carbohydrate compound family, or simple and complex carbohydrate molecules Sour refers to taste compounds or flavors that have an acidic or tart characteristic Bitter refers to alkaline compounds or flavors that provide bite, harshness, acrid or pungent reactions on the palate Salty refers to taste compounds that taste similar to, or actually is sodium chloride Umami or Savory refers to brothy or meaty taste sensation and is commonly added in the form of monosodium glutamate (MSG) Spicy refers to chemical heat and flavor of the chili or capsicum family Color or Pigment refers to changes the reflected or transmitted light as the result of wavelength-selective absorption of the food being seen Shape refers to the physical shape or form of the food Aromatic refers to the chemical compounds that transmit through the air to our olfactory system in our nose or simply the smell of the food Hot, Warm and Cold refer to the temperature of the food with hot generally above 100째F (38째C) and cold under 40째F (4째C) Tender or Soft refer to how easily food mastication or chewing occurs during food consumption Crispy or Crunchy refer to how difficult food mastication or chewing occurs during food consumption
